conclusion: The magnetic force exerted on the horizontal side of the coil that lies in the field is F = n I L B (per turn I L B, times n turns).
With the original current direction this force acts upward (or downward, depending on how the leads are connected).

premise: When the current is reversed, the force reverses as well, so its direction changes by 180°.
conclusion: Hence the force on the right arm of the balance changes from +F to –F, a net change (difference between the two situations) of ΔF = (+F) – (–F) = 2 F = 2 n I L B.
To restore equilibrium after the reversal a mass m must be placed in the left pan, producing an additional downward force mg.

premise: Equilibrium requires that this added gravitational force exactly match the change in magnetic force: mg = 2 n I L B.
conclusion: Solving for B gives B = mg / (2 n I L).
Therefore the magnitude of the magnetic–induction intensity is B = mg / (2 n I L).
